questions: What is the AI image generator?
What does the AI image generation tool do?
Can I generate images with AI in the platform?
What is the purpose of the built-in AI image generator?
answer: The AI image generator is a built-in tool that lets you create unlimited license-free images directly from your content or a custom prompt. It's fully integrated into the editor, so you can generate, save, and insert visuals into your content with just a few clicks. For more information, view this walkthrough: https://www.tailorednews.com/u/lp/ClientComms/t/c-1x-QIOpsHBtSKoiyE-QP6cbRsq3-QkW8Fk/m/e/Video-Tutorial-Page.htm

questions: How do I use the AI image generator?
Where is the image generation tool located?
How do I generate an image for my content?
How do I access the AI image feature?
answer: To use the AI image generator, drag in an image component or click on an existing image block. Then click the **Generate** button. You'll be prompted to choose an image orientation (horizontal, square, or vertical), and either write your own prompt or let the system read your content to build one for you.

questions: Can the AI tool generate a prompt for me?
What does 'generate a prompt from content' mean?
How do I auto-generate a prompt using my article?
Can AI read my content and build a prompt automatically?
answer: Yes. The AI can analyze your content and write a detailed image generation prompt for you. Just click the option to have it read your article, and it will create a rich descriptive prompt that is then passed to the image generator to create a matching visual.

questions: Can I edit the prompt before generating?
How do I customize the prompt?
Can I write my own AI image prompt?
What if I want to control exactly what the image shows?
answer: You can fully edit or replace the prompt. You can choose to edit the system-generated version or write your own from scratch. Just enter your custom text—whether it’s a style, subject, or concept—and generate the image. The tool accepts both simple and detailed prompts.

questions: Can I regenerate an image I don't like?
What if the generated image doesn’t look right?
How do I create a new version of the same image?
Can I refine or retry an AI image?
answer: If you don't like the first result, just click **Generate** again. You can tweak the prompt, remove unwanted details, or rerun the same prompt to get a new variation. The system creates unique results with every generation.

questions: Can I save AI-generated images?
How do I insert a generated image into my content?
What does 'Save' vs 'Save and Insert' mean?
Where do my AI images get stored?
answer: After generating an image, you can either click **Save** to store it in your image library, or **Save and Insert** to both store it and insert it into your current content block. You can reuse saved images later across different articles.

questions: Does the AI use my full article to generate images?
Can I control which part of my content the AI uses?
How do I edit the content used for generating the prompt?
What is the 'Edit Source' feature in image generation?
answer: By default, the tool extracts your entire article to build a prompt. But you can click **Edit Source** to manually choose which part of the content is used. This lets you fine-tune the context and control what the AI uses to create the image.

questions: Are there limits to how many AI images I can create?
Is there a usage cap on image generation?
Can I create unlimited AI images?
Do I need to pay extra to use the AI image tool?
answer: You can generate as many images as you'd like using the AI image tool. All images are license-free, and there are no limits on usage, generation frequency, or storage inside your account.

questions: What makes a good AI image prompt?
How do I write better prompts for image generation?
What should I include in my AI prompt for best results?
Any tips for writing effective AI prompts?
answer: The more specific your prompt, the better your results. Include subject, mood, setting, camera style, lighting, and artistic references if possible. For example: "A 4K photo of a Labradoodle tilting its head in a sunlit kitchen" will generate much better results than simply "dog photo."
